# Using imagery and visuals {#sec-using-imagery-and-visuals}

::: {.callout-important .unnumbered title="Summary" appearance="simple" icon="false"}
Use images sparingly. Imagery can be useful for creating ambiance or help impart information, but they should not be used to provide information alone. Images slow down page loading and increase scrolling and scanning time, especially on mobile devices.
:::

## When to use images {#sec-misconceptions-about-users-and-images}

Users are primarily visiting Library webpages are to access information or services. Therefore images and visuals should support the users aims either by informing or orientating the user.

Be wary of using images that don't do either or these things. Never rely on imagery alone to provide information. This will exclude users who cannot see or access the image.

Images can make scanning more difficult and increase scrolling time, especially on mobile devices.

Therefore use images sparingly, and remember users are just as likely to be accessing from a mobile device than a desktop or laptop computer (@sec-mobile-devices-now-account-for-50-of-webpage-views-in-the-uk).

### Decorative images

Decorative images are those which don't inform or orientate. They are used to create ambiance and should not have alt text for screen readers.
